instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - One USB-C port doesn't work.
threads.message:
Sorry, I don't know where the board number is on this one...  Complaint was USB port problems and high fan speed.  I have yet to hear the fans spin fast though.

Water damaged.  Someone has attempted to clean the board so corrosion is hard to find, but it's obvious water did hit near one of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> ICs.

Three of the four USB-C ports work fine, and will charge the machine with 20v and 2A.

However the port in the back left does not work properly.  If I plug tester in one direction I get 5v and 0A, and if I flip the connection over the tester fails to even power on.

Everything I have read says if one <CHIP>CD3515</CHIP> is bad, all USB ports will stop functioning.  If this is accurate information, does it rule out <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> problem here?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - One USB-C port doesn't work.
threads.message:
Depends of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> failure type.
Seems that you have problems on CC1/2 lines of that port.
Compare diode mode readings with the other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - One USB-C port doesn't work.
threads.message:
It looks like all four <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> have the same diode mode reading for "<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1</SIGNAL>" and "<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC2</SIGNAL>"

Around 0.588

Are there any other lines that need to be compared?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - One USB-C port doesn't work.
threads.message: Yes, the four LDO outputs of each chip...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - One USB-C port doesn't work.
threads.message:
Here are the results.  All four chips have the same diode mode measurement for the LDO rails.

All voltages are present. It seems <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> only comes up on the chip that the USB cable is plugged into. 

If I move the cable to all four ports, I can find this voltage only on three of them.  

When I plug into the "bad" port I can not find this voltage on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, which is where most of the liquid hit. 

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> -

2) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.482 / 1.8v
35) <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.513 / 0.0v  <----
53) <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.505 / 3.3v
75) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.521 / 1.8v

UB400 -

2) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.485 / 1.8v
35) <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.514 / 1.1v
53) <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.506 / 3.3v
75) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.522 / 1.8v

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> -

2) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.489 / 1.8v
35) <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.518 / 1.1v
53) <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.503 / 3.33v
75) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.528 / 1.8v

UB300 -

2) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.489 / 1.8v
35) <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.518 / 1.1v
53) <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.504 / 3.3v
75) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.526 / 1.8v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - One USB-C port doesn't work.
threads.message: You should change <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, as there you have different behaviour.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - One USB-C port doesn't work.
threads.message:
I reflowed it and it seems to have fixed the bad USB port.  

I wanted to test the machine with my USB test disk, but I can't get the boot menu to appear by holding the "options" button.  Immediately when the machine turns on the Apple logo appears and it boots customers SSD. 

Tried PRAM reset but it doesn't seem to work.  Maybe I should be treating this differently than old models?  Or is there still something broken?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - One USB-C port doesn't work.
threads.message: USB boot must be allowed first in Security Settings, inside macOS...
